item.title: Map and information / Kart og informasjon
item.description: Norsk under kartet Welcome to our biodiversity game! It is stationed in and around the Arboretum. The game consists of following hints and QR-codes through a route, answering questions about species, biodiversity and connected topics. If you want to start, find the stake near the place where the insects can check in over winter! The game is made by four students at NTNU in collaboration with the botanical garden. For more/official info about the park, take a look at the official web page.

item.title: Question 01 / Spørsmål 01
item.description: Welcome to the insect hotel! Which of these materials can be used to build an insect hotel at home? - Old logs - Pine cones - Bricks - Bamboo stems

item.title: Question 02 / Spørsmål 02
item.description: Welcome to the hillside! Here we have a question about food. Many (local) vegetables, fruits, grains and legumes like beans, peas, and potatoes emit around 0.5 kilograms of CO2 per 1000 kcal when produced. For eggs, this number is around 1 kilogram of CO2 per 1000 kcal. How many kilograms CO2 per kcal does beef (storfekjøtt) emit? - About 20 times the amount as for beans. 10.4 kg CO2 per 1000 kcal.

item.title: Question 03 / Spørsmål 03
item.description: Welcome! Here we have a question about trees! How many species of trees are there in the world? - About 30 000 - About 40 000 - About 60 000 - About 50 000

item.title: Question 04 / Spørsmål 04
item.description: Welcome! Here we have a question about alien and invasive species! Sitkagran (Sitka spruce) is an alien species in Norway. Is it unwanted here, and if so, why? - Unwanted. They are fragile and die when we plant them in norwegian territory. - Unwanted. It spreads easily, dominates natural species and prevents other species to grow on the ground close to the trees. - Barely wanted. The seeds spread easily and nourish the fields they land on, making Sitkagran a positive contribution to the biodiversity.

item.title: Question 05 / Spørsmål 05
item.description: Welcome! Here we have a question about Lichen! On which of these can lichen make their home? (grow on) - Trees - Houses - Soil - Rocks

item.title: Question 06 / Spørsmål 06
item.description: Welcome! Here we have a question about bugs! How much of the birch forests of Finnmark was eaten by butterfly larvae the summer of 2019? - About 20% - About 15% - About 10% - About 25%

item.title: Question 07 / Spørsmål 07
item.description: Welcome! Here we have a question about woodpeckers! Why does woodpeckers peck wood? - It makes loud noise proclaiming territory and contributing towards attracting a mate. - It wants to dig a nest or a roost hole. - It is feeding on the insects and larvae living in the tree sides. - They are storing food in the holes they peck.

item.title: Question 08 / Spørsmål 08
item.description: Welcome! Here we have a question about fungi and mushrooms! How does fungi/mushrooms help towards fighting environmental issues? - They help by growing on places where we can’t build anything else. - They help by digesting/breaking down unwanted materials, such as plastic, pollution, dead organic materials and even radiation! - They help by giving us delicious mushrooms we can use to cook! - They can’t help us with these problems.

item.title: Question 09 / Spørsmål 09
item.description: Welcome! Here we have a question about some mammals! Which bird is this pine tree a primary source of food for? - Harlequin duck - Siberian crows - Great spotted cuckoo - Bean goose

item.title: Question 10 / Spørsmål 10
item.description: Welcome to the center of the Arboretum, which represents the north pole! Here we have a question about the arctic and species found there! How fast can the polar bear swim? - Up to 4 km/h - They can’t swim! - Up to 10 km/h - Up to 15 km/h

item.title: Question 01 / Spørsmål 01
item.description: Welcome to the insect hotel! If you were to make a insect hotel yourself, at which wall should you place it? - North wall - East wall - South wall - West wall

item.title: Question 02 / Spørsmål 02
item.description: Welcome to the hillside! Here we have a question about food. If we assume a shopping bag full of groceries on average weigh one kg (1kg), how many shopping bags of eatable food did an average norwegian citizen throw in 2015-2016? - About 13 shopping bags of eatable food. - About 43 shopping bags of eatable food. - About 36 shopping bags of eatable food. - About 21 shopping bags of eatable food.

item.title: Question 03 / Spørsmål 03
item.description: Welcome! Here we have a question about trees! Through which process does trees and other green plants get their energy to grow? - Transpiration - Gulcolytic cycle - Photosynthesis - Algaeic thesis

item.title: Question 04 / Spørsmål 04
item.description: Welcome! Here we have a question about alien and invasive species! How many alien species (from 2018) are on the norwegian list of species causing high risk to the norwegian biodiversity? How many alien species are listed in total? - Around 1500 causing high risk, 3100 foreign species in total - Around 230 causing high risk, 1500 foreign species in total - Around 300 causing high risk, 1200 foreign species in total - Around 80 causing high risk, 230 foreign species in total

item.title: Question 05 / Spørsmål 05
item.description: Welcome! Here we have a question about lichens! Which two organisms make up lichen? - Algae and lizard - Algae and fungus - Fungus and corals - Corals and algae

item.title: Question 06 / Spørsmål 06
item.description: Welcome! Here we have a question about bugs! How many differen species of bark beetles exist? - 4000 - 3300 - 2500 - 6000

item.title: Question 07 / Spørsmål 07
item.description: Welcome! Here we have a question about woodpeckers! What is NOT true about the woodpecker? - Woodpeckers use small helmets in order to not get concussions when pecking. - When pecking, the woodpecker can ecperience g forces up to 1200 g’s. - Woodpeckers rely on old and rotten forest in order to build homes. - The woodpecker’s skull is bade of soft, sponge-like bone material

item.title: Question 08 / Spørsmål 08
item.description: Welcome! Here we have a question about fungi and mushrooms! Why are fungi/mushrooms important for nature and biodiversity? - Some species break down organic elements, such as dead plants or trees, and work as natures “recylcer” to bring nutrients back into nature. - Some species act as food for animals, and the animals aid them to reproduce. - Some species act as the “middle man” between plants and the soil, extracting nutrients from the soil trading with the plants.

item.title: Question 09 / Spørsmål 09
item.description: Welcome! Here we have a question about some mammals! How long does crow couples usually stick together? - until the chicks are grown - Their entire lives - they don’t stick toether - Until the eggs are done

item.title: Question 10 / Spørsmål 10
item.description: Welcome to the center of the Arboretum, which represents the north pole! Here we have a question about the arctic and species found there! How much has the temperature increased in the Arctic, compared to the rest of the world? - Twice as much - Half as much - Three times as much - Equally

item.title: Question 01 / Spørsmål 01
item.description: Welcome to the insect hotel! Do we need to move the insect hotel inside during winter? - Yes - No - Only if a snow storm is coming - Only if it’s below -20 degrees

item.title: Question 02 / Spørsmål 02
item.description: Welcome to the hillside! Here we have a question about food. We throw a lot of food in Norway. How many people could we have fed if we halved the food waste in the country? - About 500 000 people, which is more than the total population of Trøndelag per 2020. - About 200 000 people, which is more than the total population of Trondheim per 2020. - About 370 000 people, which is about the population of Innlandet County per 2021.

item.title: Question 03 / Spørsmål 03
item.description: Welcome! Here we have a question about trees! Where in the tree does photosynthesis happen? - In the roots - Only at the upper top - In the leaves/the green part - In the stem

item.title: Question 04 / Spørsmål 04
item.description: Welcome! Here we have a question about alien and invasive species! There are many foreign species. How should you treat foreign plants, trees, etc..? - Unwanted. They are fragile and die when we plant them in norwegian territory. - Be cautious! Read about them and make sure they are wanted in your area and will cause no harm before deciding what to do. - Plant them! Nature can handle it, therefore the best is to return them to nature.

item.title: Question 05 / Spørsmål 05
item.description: Welcome! Here we have a question about lichens! Which of these is not a type/family of lichen? - Crustose - Gandalf - Foliose - Fruticose

item.title: Question 06 / Spørsmål 06
item.description: Welcome! Here we have a question about bugs! How many life stages does bark beetles undergo? (if they survive) - Three - Two - Five - Four

item.title: Question 07 / Spørsmål 07
item.description: Welcome! Here we have a question about woodpeckers! How long is the woodpecker’s tongue, compared to its bill? - About twice the length. - About thrice the length. - About equal length. - About half the length.

item.title: Question 08 / Spørsmål 08
item.description: Welcome! Here we have a question about fungi and mushrooms! Does mushroom need light to grow? - For at least some parts of the day - No - They need some light, but only during the growing season - Yes, a lot of sunlight, but not necessarily direct sunlight

item.title: Question 09 / Spørsmål 09
item.description: Welcome! Here we have a question about some mammals! Which of these are not a type of bear? - Sloth bear - Moon bear - tPolar bear - Panda bear

item.title: Question 10 / Spørsmål 10
item.description: Welcome to the center of the Arboretum, which represents the north pole! Here we have a question about the arctic and species found there! How fast is the perennial ice melting? - 5 % melts every ten years - 2 % melts every ten years - 10 % melts every ten years - 8 % melts every ten years

item.title: Correct! Great job! (Q_1_01)
item.description: Congratulations! Your answer was correct. In fact, all the answers were correct! You can use most materials for insect hotels! The next question can be found by following this hint: To the two-tree-wonder at the orchard gardens edge! Where the Siberian Apricot (Prunus sibirica) is the first to awaken from the Winter slumber, offering Spring blooms to pollinators so they can drink its nectar. Eager to learn more?

item.title: Correct! Great job! (Q_1_02)
item.description: Congratulations! Your answer was correct. The production of beef emits large amounts of CO2 per 1000 kcal, suggesting that eating less beef (or quitting beef totally) is the most eco-friendly. The next question can be found by following this hint: From the dying tree a bear was born! When Purpuredelgran (Abies amabilis) could stand no more due to a fungus infection, Oliver Vogt came with his chainsaw to carve it into perfection!

item.title: Correct! Great job! (Q_1_03)
item.description: Congratulations! Your answer was correct. A 2017 report states that there are 60.000 known species of trees in our world. The next question can be found by following this hint: Introduced to Norway in the 19th century as a lumber tree, the Sitkagran (Picea sitchensis) is the largest spruce in the world, growing to almost 100 meters tall! But sadly where it’s needles fall, you’ll find no trace of life at all.

item.title: Correct! Great job! (Q_1_04)
item.description: Congratulations! Your answer was correct. Sitkagran (Sitka spruce) spreads easily and dominates other species. The next question can be found by following this hint: Now you find yourself in the arboretum. Head south-east along the path to make your way to the Blågran (Picea pungens) which plays host to seven species of lichen! Look closely, can you find them? Eager to learn more? Invasive species are a problem.

item.title: Correct! Great job! (Q_1_05)
item.description: Congratulations! Your answer was correct. In fact, all the answers were correct! Lichen can even grow on sand! The next question can be found by following this hint: Pass the wooden rabbit to find logs of the Svartgran (Picea Mariana) with mysterious hieroglyphs engraved into their surface! These patterns are actually the paths of the larvae of the trebukk beetle as it feasts upon dead wood! Eager to learn more?

item.title: Correct! Great job! (Q_1_06)
item.description: Congratulations! Your answer was correct. In 2019, 10 000 square km in Norway, Sweden and Finland were attacked by the larvae, and a large portion of the forest was also killed. The larvae are originally a southernmore speci, but has begun to invade further north as the temperature has risen. The next question can be found by following this hint: Continue along the path until you meet the wise old owl.

item.title: Correct! Great job! (Q_1_07)
item.description: Congratulations! Your answer was correct. In fact, all the answers were correct! The next question can be found by following this hint: Moving along the windy road, find the birch log (Betula pubescens) where the wild things thrive and the mushrooms grow. Eager to learn more? Woodpeckers are interesting creatures! Read more about them here, here or here.

item.title: Correct! Great job! (Q_1_08)
item.description: Congratulations! Your answer was correct. Mushrooms/fungi work as natures number one recycler! The next question can be found by following this hint: On and on you must go, to find the meeting point of the squirrel, the sparrow and the crow. Gathering under the Sibirsk sembrafuru (Pinus cembra) bows, they are friends and not foe. Eager to learn more? Fungi/mushrooms are responsible for a vast amount of the processes we see in nature.

item.title: Correct! Great job! (Q_1_09)
item.description: Congratulations! Your answer was correct. The next question can be found by following this hint: Finally, of to North Pole you go, where you may rest your weary bones.

item.title: Correct! Great job! (Q_1_10)
item.description: Congratulations! Your answer was correct. Even though the polar bear is a good swimmer, it is relying on moving on ice to hunt for food, resting and eating. This is the end of the game. Feel free to enjoy the rest of the gardens. If you want to play again (or started midways), follow this hint to get to the first question. Find the cozy hotel on the hill where the insects like to spend their winter, to start on your adventure.

item.title: Sorry, wrong answer! (Q_1_02)
item.description: We’re sorry! Your answer was not correct. Try again here! Eager to learn more? For a more complete list of emissions, take a look here. WHO has a list of what should be included in a healthy diet, suggesting that vegetarian and mediterranian diets are the most healthy, both for you and for the environment.

Unfortunately, some of the trees in the botanical garden needs to be felled due to fungus infection as a consequence of global warming. If you want to find more interesting facts about trees, see here.

item.description: Congratulations! Your answer was correct. The south wall is usually the warmest, which insects are quite fond of. Most materials can be used to build insect hotels, most important is it to give the insects shelter and safe space.

item.title: Correct! Great job! (Q_2_02)
item.description: Congratulations! Your answer was correct. We consumers throw a lot of food, usually because we follow the “best before” date strictly instead of evaluating in each case whether or not the food is good or bad. The next question can be found by following this hint: From the dying tree a bear was born! When Purpuredelgran (Abies amabilis) could stand no more due to a fungus infection, Oliver Vogt came with his chainsaw to carve it into perfection!

item.title: Correct! Great job! (Q_2_03)
item.description: Congratulations! Your answer was correct. Photosynthesis is the biochemical reaction through which all green plants, including trees, make their food to live and grow. The next question can be found by following this hint: Introduced to Norway in the 19th century as a lumber tree, the Sitkagran (Picea sitchensis) is the largest spruce in the world, growing to almost 100 meters tall! But sadly where it’s needles fall, you’ll find no trace of life at all.

item.title: Correct! Great job! (Q_2_04)
item.description: Congratulations! Your answer was correct. There are (per 2018) around 230 causing high risk and 1500 foreign species in total. The next question can be found by following this hint: Now you find yourself in the arboretum. item.title: Correct! Great job! (Q_2_05)
item.description: Congratulations! Your answer was correct. The next question can be found by following this hint: Pass the wooden rabbit to find logs of the Svartgran (Picea Mariana) with mysterious hieroglyphs engraved into their surface! These patterns are actually the paths of the larvae of the trebukk beetle as it feasts upon dead wood! Eager to learn more? Lichen are formed when algae and fungus combine. The color of the lichen is determined by the color of the algae.

item.title: Correct! Great job! (Q_2_06)
item.description: Congratulations! Your answer was correct. The next question can be found by following this hint: Continue along the path until you meet the wise old owl. Follow his steady gaze across your way to find the Flagspett nest in the Gråor (Salix Incana) tree, it looks more like a hollow! Eager to learn more? The bark beetles reproduce in the bark of the tree! During mating season, one single male beetle can be followed by up to fifty female beetles.

item.title: Correct! Great job! (Q_2_07)
item.description: Congratulations! Your answer was correct. Even though woodpeckers do not use helmets, their skull is so robust and suited for shock absorbtion that helmet designers use them as inspiration. The next question can be found by following this hint: Moving along the windy road, find the birch log (Betula pubescens) where the wild things thrive and the mushrooms grow. Eager to learn more? Woodpeckers are interesting creatures!

item.title: Correct! Great job! (Q_2_08)
item.description: Congratulations! Your answer was correct. In fact, all the answers were correct. Fungi/mushrooms are amazing, and they work as natures number one recycler! The next question can be found by following this hint: On and on you must go, to find the meeting point of the squirrel, the sparrow and the crow. Gathering under the Sibirsk sembrafuru (Pinus cembra) bows, they are friends and not foe. Eager to learn more?

item.title: Correct! Great job! (Q_2_09)
item.description: Congratulations! Your answer was correct. The crow is monogamous and the couples believably stick together their entire lives. The couple build a nest for the family, consisting of sdry twigs, dirt and clay, lined with hair, gras, wool and bark. The next question can be found by following this hint: Finally, of to North Pole you go, where you may rest your weary bones.

item.title: Correct! Great job! (Q_2_10)
item.description: Congratulations! Your answer was correct. Observations show that the Arctic average surface temperature between 1979 and 2019 increased three times as much as the temperature increased on average in the rest of the world, according to the Arctic Monitoring and Assessment Programme (AMAP). This is the end of the game. Feel free to enjoy the rest of the gardens. If you want to play again (or started midways), follow this hint to get to the first question.

item.title: Sorry, wrong answer! (Q_2_01)

Try not to paint or laquer your hotel, as the insects might be sceptical towards the chemicals. Learn how to build an insect hotel!

item.description: Congratulations! Your answer was correct. We do not need to move the insect hotel inside during winter! The next question can be found by following this hint: Introduced to Norway in the 19th century as a lumber tree, the Sitkagran (Picea sitchensis) is the largest spruce in the world, growing to almost 100 meters tall! But sadly where it’s needles fall, you’ll find no trace of life at all.

item.title: Correct! Great job! (Q_3_07)
item.description: Congratulations! Your answer was correct. Woodpeckers have super long tongues, usually twice the length of their beaks! This is useful when reaching to eat insects inside the holes they peck. The next question can be found by following this hint: Moving along the windy road, find the birch log (Betula pubescens) where the wild things thrive and the mushrooms grow. Eager to learn more? Woodpeckers are interesting creatures!

item.title: Correct! Great job! (Q_3_08)
item.description: Congratulations! Your answer was correct. Mushrooms can survive well without light. Unlike green plants using photosynthesis, mushrooms use the compost they are growing in/on to get the enery they need. The next question can be found by following this hint: On and on you must go, to find the meeting point of the squirrel, the sparrow and the crow. Gathering under the Sibirsk sembrafuru (Pinus cembra) bows, they are friends and not foe.

item.title: Correct! Great job! (Q_3_09)
item.description: Congratulations! Your answer was correct. There are actually eitght different types of bear - north american black bear, brown bear, polar bear, asiatic black bear, andean bear, panda bear, sloth bear, and the sun bear. The next question can be found by following this hint: Finally, of to North Pole you go, where you may rest your weary bones.

item.title: Correct! Great job! (Q_3_10)
item.description: Congratulations! Your answer was correct. The perennial ice is the ice that “survives” the hot summer. When this ice is melting, the polar bears' and other arctic species get their survival conditions worsened:-( This is the end of the game. Feel free to enjoy the rest of the gardens. item.description: We’re sorry! Your answer was not correct. Try again here! Eager to learn more? The bark beetles reproduce in the bark of the tree! During mating season, one single male beetle can be followed by up to fifty female beetles. Read about them here or here. Climate change is affecting where bugs live, which in turn affects the ecosystems around the planet. Read more about how this damaged a lot of forests in Finnmark here.
